selected_quotes: Love that the Paenobacillus genome paper referenced by Ingram has some videos of swarming motility #SocialMicrobes12

citation.abstract: The pattern-forming bacterium Paenibacillus vortex is notable for its advanced social behavior, which is reflected in development of colonies with highly intricate architectures. Prior to this study, only two other Paenibacillus species (Paenibacillus sp. JDR-2 and Paenibacillus larvae) have been sequenced. However, no genomic data is available on the Paenibacillus species with pattern-forming and complex social motility. Here we report the de novo genome sequence of this Gram-positive, soil-dwelling, sporulating bacterium.
citation.title: Genome sequence of the pattern forming Paenibacillus vortex bacterium reveals potential for thriving in complex environments

author.description: 生物地学環境人文科学等オタクです。勉強の忘備録兼ねてRTしています※大量。夜にまとめてTL読むことが多い。生物画像どんと来い！ 科学ジャーナか環境コンサル志望叶わずこじらせ厨糞ニート。ノーモアパクツイ、エロお断り。RTフォローリムーブご自由に。通知不調。ミュートする位ならリムーブして下さい。

author.name: 日経サイエンス
author.description: 『日経サイエンス』は世界的な視野から、科学の最新トピックス、ニュースを幅広く、深く、面白く伝えるポピュラー・サイエンス誌です。世界の第一線で活躍する一流の科学者、ジャーナリストたちが、科学の最前線とその成果がもたらすインパクトを一般の方に向けてビジュアルにわかりやすく解説しています。

video.title: Dynamic imaging of swarming of Paenibacillus vortex by light microscopy
video.summary:
Single branch of a swarming culture moving on MH (1.5% w/v) agar is presented. Magnification 400× and 4 times the actual speed.
Reference for this video is http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2164/11/710

video.title: Movement of a single vortex of Paenibacillus vortex
video.summary:
500× magnification and twice the real speed
reference of this video is: Sirota-Madi et al. BMC Genomics 2010, 11:710
http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2164/11/710

video.title: Early stage of colony organization of Paenibacillus vortex
video.summary:
The magnification is 50× magnification and 60× rate
Reference for this video is:http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2164/11/710

wikipedia.title: Paenibacillus
wikipedia.summary: Paenibacillus is a genus of facultative anaerobic, endospore-forming bacteria, originally included within the genus Bacillus and then reclassified as a separate genus in 1993.
